Name: 2,4,5-TP
Description: Fenoprop is a monocarboxylic acid. It has a role as a phenoxy herbicide.

environmental_bioconcentrations.References: (1) Garten CT, Trabalka JR; Environ Sci Technol 17: 590-5 (1983) (2) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994) (3) US EPA; Herbicide report: chemistry and analysis environmental effects agricultural and other applied uses.US EPA, Haz Mat Advis Comm, Science Advisory Board, Washington, DC: USEPA-SAB-74-001; NTIS PB 266 006, pp 212 (1974)
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: A BCF of 58 was reported in fish in flowing water for 2,4,5-TP(1). According to a classification scheme(2), this BCF data suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is moderate(SRC). 2,4,5-TP does not appear to bioconcentrate more than 10 fold(3).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Smith AE; Weed Res 18: 275-9 (1978) (2) Alexander M, Aleem MIH; J Agric Food Chem 9: 44-7 (1961) (3) Chau ASY, Thomson K; J Assoc Off Anal Chem 61: 1481-5 (1978) (4) City of Jacksonville, AK; Water Pollut Control Res Ser NTIS PB-206813 178 pp (1971) (5) Johnson B; Setting Revised Specific Numerical Values. April 1991 EH 91-6 Calif Dept Food Agric, Environmental Hazards Assessment Program 17 pp (1991) (6) Kozak VP et al; Reviews of the environmental fate of pollutants: XI. Chlorophenols USEPA-600/1-79-012 (1979) (7) Smith AE; Rev Weed Sci 4: 1-24 (1989) (8) Weber JB; Golf Superintendent 42: 12-4 (1974) (9) Zipper C et al; FEMS Microbiol Ecol 29: 197-204 (1999)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: AEROBIC: Half-lives for biodegradation of 2,4,5-TP in three Saskatchewan, Canada prairie soils were 13, 13 and 10 days for heavy clay loam, clay loam and sandy loam, respectively(1). Negligible degradation was observed in air-dried soils(1). Biodegradation of 2,4,5-TP was tested in Mardin, Honeoye and Dunkirk silt loam soil samples from areas in NY, resulting in complete disappearance in greater than 47, 124 and 205 days, respectively(2). 2,4,5-TP was shown to have an aerobic half-life of 16 days in soil(5). 2,4,5-Trichlorophenol has been identified as a product of the biodegradation of 2,4,5-TP(6). 2,4,5-TP was shown to have a half-life of 8 and 10 days in sandy loam, 15 and 21 days in forest soil, 13 days in clay loam and 14 days in grassland soil(7). In soil, 2,4,5-TP was reported to degrade more slowly than 2,4-D(8). No biodegradation of 2,4,5-TP was observed after 50 days incubation in Hamilton Harbour water from Ontario, Canada(3). An initial concn of 2,4,5-TP of 107.5 ppm was completely degraded in lagoon water in 9 days after 100 ml of 2,4,5-trichlorophenol acclimated water was added and incubated at 20 to 21 °C with constant aeration(4). 2,4,5-TP, incubated at 25 °C with sewage sludge in an aeration tank for 47 days gave an unchanged concentration of the S enantiomer and a 40% decrease in the R enantiomer(9).

environmental_biodegradations.References: Menzie, C.M. Metabolism of Pesticides-Update III. Special Scientific Report- Wildlife No. 232. Washington, DC: U.S.Department of the Interior, Fish and Wildlife Service, 1980., p. 206
environmental_biodegradations.Value: Pseudomonas species & Achromobacter species from farm pond were unable individually to degrade 2,4,5-TP. However, when a mixed culture of these two organisms was incubated with 2,4,5-TP ... degradation occurred. Chlorine was released as chloride; the ring was cleaved; & carbon dioxide was evolved. One metabolite was identified as 2,4,5-trichlorophenol.

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Johnson B; Setting Revised Specific Numerical Values. April 1991 EH 91-6 Calif Dept Food Agric, Environmental Hazards Assessment Program 17 pp (1991)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: ANAEROBIC: 2,4,5-TP was shown to have an anaerobic half-life of 32 days(1).

logP.References: Hansch, C., Leo, A., D. Hoekman. Exploring QSAR - Hydrophobic, Electronic, and Steric Constants. Washington, DC: American Chemical Society., 1995., p. 51

mechanism_of_action.References: Abo-Khatwa N, Hollingworth RM; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 12 (4): 446-54 (1981) as cited in Vet Admin Rev Lit on Herbicides Vol 2 p.1 (1981) VA Contract No. V101(93)p-823)
mechanism_of_action.Value: At 1x10-5 M, 2,4,5-TP reduced the respiratory control index, stimulated the state 4 respiration rate, and reduced the ADP to oxygen ratio /in rat liver mitochondrial suspensions/. /It was/ concluded that /2,4,5-TP/ was an uncoupler of respiratory chain phosphorylation.

mechanism_of_action.References: Weed Science Society of America. Herbicide Handbook. 5th ed. Champaign, Illinois: Weed Science Society of America, 1983., p. 431
Doull, J., C.D.Klassen, and M.D. Amdur (eds.). Casarett and Doull's Toxicology. 3rd ed., New York: Macmillan Co., Inc., 1986., p. 554
mechanism_of_action.Value: They exert their herbicidal action by acting as a growth hormone in plants. They have no hormonal action in animals, but their mechanism of toxic action is poorly understood. /Chlorophenoxy compounds/

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: National Research Council. Drinking Water & Health Volume 1. Washington, DC: National Academy Press, 1977., p. 513
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/ In rats & rabbits, the oral LD50 of the mixed butyl esters & propylene glycol esters ranged between 500 & 1,000 mg/kg. /Silvex esters/

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Gosselin, R.E., R.P. Smith, H.C. Hodge. Clinical Toxicology of Commercial Products. 5th ed. Baltimore: Williams and Wilkins, 1984., p. II-325
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Subchronic or Prechronic Exposure/ After admin of 50 mg/kg to cattle daily for 90 days, erosion of the rumen mucosa & chronic enteritis were observed. Necropsy findings included enlarged & friable liver & congestion of the lower respiratory passages.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: National Research Council. Drinking Water & Health Volume 1. Washington, DC: National Academy Press, 1977., p. 514
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Subchronic or Prechronic Exposure/ The propylene glycol butyl ether ester of Silvex (Kuron) was fed to male & female rats in diet at 10, 30, 100, 300 & 600 mg/kg/day for 90 days /strain not specified/. mortalities were observed at 600 mg/kg/day, growth decr at 300 & 600 mg/kg/day, & incr liver wt at 30 mg/kg/day & above. No toxic effect was found in animals receiving 10 mg/kg/day. /Propylene glycol butyl ether ester of Silvex (Kuron)/

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's Integrated Risk Information System (IRIS) on 2(2,4,5-Trichlorophenoxy) propionic acid (2,4,5-TP) (CAS # 93-72-1). Available from the Database Query page at: https://www.epa.gov/iris/subst/index.html on the Substance File List as of February 14, 2008.
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Chronic Exposure or Carcinogenicity/ ... A 2-year study in which groups of 25 male and 25 female rats were fed diets containing 0, 10, 30, or 100 ppm Kurosal SL. No effects on general appearance, food consumption, hematological parameters, blood chemistry, or gross and microscopic appearance of tissues were observed. Slightly retarded growth and increased relative kidney weights were the only adverse effects observed, and they occurred only at 100 ppm. No adverse effects occurred at 30 ppm or less, equivalent to 2.6 mg/kg/day of the acid form of silvex. /Kurosal SL/

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's Integrated Risk Information System (IRIS) on 2(2,4,5-Trichlorophenoxy) propionic acid (2,4,5-TP) (CAS # 93-72-1). Available from the Database Query page at: https://www.epa.gov/iris/subst/index.html on the Substance File List as of February 14, 2008.
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Chronic Exposure or Carcinogenicity/ Groups of four male and four female dogs received Kurosal SL at doses of 56, 190, or 560 ppm of diet for 2 years. Since this formulation contains the potassium salt of Silvex equivalent to approximately 53% of the acid form of silvex, these dietary levels are 30, 101 and 297 ppm of the acid equivalent of Silvex ... equivalent to doses of 0, 0.75, 2.5 and 7.4 mg/kg/day. The parameters monitored in this study included weekly body weight, food consumption, hematology, serum biochemistry and histopathology of target organs. The only observed adverse effects were dose-related histopathological changes in the livers of female dogs receiving the high dose and in males receiving the mid and high dose. No adverse effects on growth, food consumption, hematological parameters, or other tissues were observed. Thus, 0.75 mg/kg/day was the NOEL.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's Integrated Risk Information System (IRIS) on 2(2,4,5-Trichlorophenoxy) propionic acid (2,4,5-TP) (CAS # 93-72-1). Available from the Database Query page at: https://www.epa.gov/iris/subst/index.html on the Substance File List as of February 14, 2008.
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Chronic Exposure or Carcinogenicity/ ... Incidences /of tumors/ were not increased at any site in B6C3F1 or B6AKF1 mice (18/sex/strain) that were treated orally by gavage from 7 to 28 days of age with 46.4 mg/kg/day of 2,4,5-TP in 0.5% gelatin, and subsequently maintained for 76 to 77 wk on a diet that contained 121 ppm 2,4,5-TP ... Elevated incidences of tumors were also not observed at any specific sites in the same strains of mice (18/sex/strain) 18 mo after single sc injections of 215 mg/kg 2,4,5-TP (in dimethyl sulfoxide) on day 28 of age. Complete necropsies that included gross and histological examination of major organs and tissues were performed on all treated and control animals. Male B6C3F1 mice that were treated orally or by sc injection did show a higher incidence of total tumors (8/17 and 7/18 in treated vs 22/79 and 2/24 in controls, respectively), but this was not apparent in female B6C3F1 or B6AKF1 mice of either sex.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's Integrated Risk Information System (IRIS) on 2(2,4,5-Trichlorophenoxy) propionic acid (2,4,5-TP) (CAS # 93-72-1). Available from the Database Query page at: https://www.epa.gov/iris/subst/index.html on the Substance File List as of February 14, 2008.
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Chronic Exposure or Carcinogenicity/ ... No increased incidence of tumors /was found/ in male or female Wistar rats that were fed 2,4,5-TP potassium salt at levels of 0, 0.26, 0.8, 2.6 or 7.9 mg acid equivalent/kg/day for 2 years.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: National Research Council. Drinking Water & Health Volume 1. Washington, DC: National Academy Press, 1977., p. 515
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Developmental or Reproductive Toxicity/ ... Sprague-Dawley rats were given 2,4,5-trichlorophenoxypropionic acid at 25, 50, 75, 100 mg/kg/day on days 6-15 of gestation or 50, 75, or 100 mg/kg/day from day 6 of gestation through lactation. A few maternal deaths occurred at 100 mg/kg/day; dosage of 75 mg/kg/day produced alopecia & vaginal bleeding. Minor alopecia was seen at 50 mg/kg/day. Terata were seen at 50 mg/kg/day, but were minor & related to incomplete ossification of the skull. Mean pup wt were ... decr at 50 mg/kg/day & above. Dosage with no-adverse-fetotoxic effects was considered to be 25 mg/kg/day.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: National Research Council. Drinking Water & Health Volume 1. Washington, DC: National Academy Press, 1977., p. 515
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Developmental or Reproductive Toxicity/ ... The effects of 2,4,5-TP containing TCDD /2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin/ at less than 0.1 ppm on pregnant CD-1 strain mice & their offspring /were studied/. Animals received 2,4,5-TP daily at 398 mg/kg/day orally or sc on days 12-15 of gestation. Controls had no cleft palates, whereas the herbicide produced 3% (oral) or 7% (sc) cleft palates in the fetuses. There was also a significant incr in maternal liver:body-wt ratios in treated mice.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Doull, J., C.D.Klassen, and M.D. Amdur (eds.). Casarett and Doull's Toxicology. 3rd ed., New York: Macmillan Co., Inc., 1986., p. 554
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Developmental or Reproductive Toxicity/ Concern about the toxicology of 2,4,5-T & related compounds centers primarily on teratogenic action in exptl animals. The first studies to reveal this action were ... conducted with a sample of 2,4,5-T that contained a high level (about 30 ppm) of contaminant, 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin. This contaminant is formed during synthesis of the trichlorophenol precursor. /Chlorophenoxy compounds/

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's Integrated Risk Information System (IRIS) on 2(2,4,5-Trichlorophenoxy) propionic acid (2,4,5-TP) (CAS # 93-72-1). Available from the Database Query page at: https://www.epa.gov/iris/subst/index.html on the Substance File List as of February 14, 2008.
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /GENOTOXICITY/ The mutagenicity of 2,4,5-TP for Salmonella typhimurium was evaluated in one study (spot test) and found to be negative ...

/OTHER TOXICITY INFORMATION/ Male Sprague-Dawley rats were given Silvex by sc injection or through dietary exposure. Dose level of 100 mg/kg decr p-aminohippurate and 2,4,5-T accumulation into renal cortical slices by 34%, respectively. Dietary exposure over prolonged periods to Silvex caused a significant decr in renal organic anion and cation transport.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Doull, J., C.D.Klassen, and M.D. Amdur (eds.). Casarett and Doull's Toxicology. 3rd ed., New York: Macmillan Co., Inc., 1986., p. 554
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /OTHER TOXICITY INFORMATION/ Pathologic changes in exptl animals killed by the chlorophenoxy compounds are generally nonspecific with irritation of stomach & some liver & kidney injury. /Chlorophenoxy compounds/

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's Integrated Risk Information System (IRIS) on 2(2,4,5-Trichlorophenoxy) propionic acid (2,4,5-TP) (CAS # 93-72-1). Available from the Database Query page at: https://www.epa.gov/iris/subst/index.html on the Substance File List as of February 14, 2008.
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /OTHER TOXICITY INFORMATION/ Commercial 2,4,5-TP contains as a contaminant 2,3,7,8-tetrachloro- dibenzo-p-dioxin, a known animal carcinogen.

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Carey AE, Kutz FW; Environ Assess 5: 155-63 (1985)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: 2,4,5-TP was found in sediments in 0.2% of samples taken in a National Water Monitoring Program conducted in the US nationwide from 1976 to 1980; an average concentration of 6.3 ppb was reported(1).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Webber MD, Wang C; Can J Soil Sci 75: 513-24 (1995)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SOIL: 2,4,5-TP was detected in 10 agricultural surface soils from Ontario, Saskatchewan, and Alberta, Canada at concentrations ranging from 2.6 to 29 mg/kg(1).

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) Jafvert CT; Environ Toxicol Chem 9: 1259-68 (1990) (2) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983) (3) Almendros G; Eur J Soil Sci 46: 287-301 (1995) (4) Augustijn-Beckers PWM et al; Rev Environ Contam Toxicol 137: 1-82 (1994) (5) Weber JB; Golf Superintendent 42: 12-4 (1974) (6) Tomlin CDS, ed; 2,4,5-TP (93-72-1). In: The e-Pesticide Manual, 13th Edition V 3.1 (2004-05). Surrey UK, British Crop Protection Council. (7) Doucette WJ; pp. 141-188 in Handbook of Property Estimation Methods for Chemicals. Boethling RS, Mackay D, eds. Boca Raton, FL: Lewis Publ (2000)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: Log Koc values for 2,4,5-TP have been reported as 1.87 and 2.03(1), giving Koc values of 74 and 107. According to a classification scheme(2), these Koc values suggest that 2,4,5-TP will have high mobility in soil(SRC). 2,4,5-TP had sorption values of 2.7-5.9 mg/kg at different conditions in soil with a pH of 7.4, and sorption values of 0.2-1.1 mg/kg in soil with a pH of 8.2(3). 2,4,5-TP had reported sorption coefficients of 308-9016 mL/g(4). 2,4,5-TP is expected to be negatively charged and will not be readily absorbed making it more mobile in soil(5). The pKa of 2,4,5-TP is 2.84(6), indicating that this compound will exist almost entirely in anion form in the environment and anions generally do not adsorb more strongly to soils containing organic carbon and clay than their neutral counterparts(7).
